sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Welcome to Euronews tonight. I'm Eamon Zaidi. Here are the headlines.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Sergei Tikhanovsky, the husband of Belarus' opposition leader Svetlana Tikhanovskaya, is jailed for 18 years for organising riots and inciting social hatred.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And I've caught up with Svetlana Tikhanovskaya here in Brussels.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: She said she won't tell her youngest child about her father's 18-year prison sentence but she vows to fight on.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: WHO says Omicron spreading at unprecedented rate. It's now been detected in 77 countries.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: As cases rise in the UK, the parliament debates extending restrictions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Here in the Cube, we take a look at the latest example of COVID-related violence as a Greek school teacher is abducted by vigilantes.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And Malta becomes the first European country to legalise cannabis for personal use.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: The husband of Belarus' opposition leader, Svetlana Tikhanovskaya has been jailed for 18 years.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Sergei Tikhanovsky was convicted of organising mass unrest and of inciting social hatred.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: He was arrested in 2020 ahead of the presidential election in which he planned to run against Alexander Lukashenko.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: The disputed result that saw Lukashenko claim victory and extend his 28 years in power saw mass protests on the street of the country.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Well, for more, we're now joined by Shona Murray, a correspondent in Brussels.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Shona, good to see you. So you've been talking to Svetlana today following the sentencing of her husband.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: What did she have to say?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: Well, the last time they spoke was actually October last year 2020 and she knew this day was coming. She knew that this trial was behind closed doors. I spoke to her a few weeks ago. She expected him to get around 15 years but she told me that when she was given the information that it was 18 years she was still in shock because you can't prepare for shocking news like that and obviously she's deeply concerned about about his condition and i caught up with her and i asked her first of all for her reaction i knew that the sentence will be on this day and i was sure that i'm ready for any news i knew that it would be like very tough sentence but you can't be prepared for such things and i was at the meeting when one of my assistant told me that 18 years i understood everything you know i couldn't burst into tears at this moment because i had to continue this visit but of course something was torn inside of me. But, you know, it's difficult to imagine. It's impossible to imagine this number at all because it's the longest sentence any person had from political prisoners.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_02
sentences.sentence: I understand that it's personal revenge, revenge on my husband, who managed to organize people around himself, to manage to raise up people, and maybe it's revenge on me.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: That's Svetlana Tyanovskaya speaking to me earlier today in Brussels.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: She also told me that she doesn't intend to tell her young daughter, who's just turned six, about her father's 18-year sentence.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Her daughter doesn't know that he's in prison.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: She thinks he's on a business trip.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: But she constantly asks where her father is and she will tell her 11-year-old son about this sentence, but obviously a huge thing for any child to try to understand.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Absolutely.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Now, Svetlana says that the

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: only question she will ask herself is what will she do next? So what is she planning now?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Well, she really has no choice but to fight on. I mean, she's here in Brussels today ahead of a European Council meeting over the next two days of EU leaders where Belarus will feature quite strongly anyway, regardless. I mean, this was going to happen anyway but of course Sergei's sentencing will certainly be a major part of the discussion between all member states and first of all they'll be discussing how to react and I have spoken to EU source today who said that member states would be open to even a sixth round of sanctions against belarus on after only just passing a recent round a couple of weeks ago the fifth round of sanctions but for svetlana tinovskaya she has to continue she is the exiled opposition leader of belarus as you mentioned earlier of course her husband was going to run against alexander lukashenko he wasn't even able to file the papers to do so. He was arrested, and so she filed her name.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: And so her role now is to continue until there is eventually democratic elections in Belarus.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Shona Murray in Brussels, thank you so much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Well, for more analysis, I'm now joined by journalist Hanna Lubakova,

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: a non-resident fellow at the Atlantic Council.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Hanna, so Svetlana says she feels the sentence handed down to her husband is not only personal revenge on him, but on her also.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_08
sentences.sentence: Is that how it's being viewed in Belarus?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: I think it's a pretty correct description.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Svetlana Tikhanovskaya ran in the election just because her husband was not registered and she became so popular she was able to gather support among the population, among the society and now Lukashenko imposes revenge on her, on Sergei and basically on every Belarusian who protested against him because he wants to scare people. He wants to show that anybody who is going out on the streets who protests against him would be jailed for so many years.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So this is a revenge on basically the society in general.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Now, Tsikhanouski joins hundreds of dissenting voices behind bars, some are high profile, others not so well known.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: dissenting voices behind bars, some are high profile, others not so well known?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: So there is this blogger, Igor Oosik, who has been jailed for 15 years and he was actually arrested last year in June. Mikhail Estatkevich is a prominent politician who's been around forever.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: He was also in the 90s at the same time when Lukashenko came to power, so Lukashenko perfectly well knows him and remembers him and Mikhail Estetkevich was sentenced today to 14 years in prison. Like these sentences are the harshest, are the most brutal in the history of modern Belarus when it comes to opposition politicians. So it just shows the level of fear of Lukashenko when it comes to discontent, when it comes to opposition, when it comes to democratic forces.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: But I think what's positive here, if anything, but many people do not believe that Sergei Tikhanovsky or Mikhail Stetkevich or Igor Osik would be in jail for so many years. It's just not possible. People do not believe that the regime would be able to stay in power for so long. So I think that's this prevalent feeling among Belarusians, that despite anything, they would not stay behind bars for so many years.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: anything, they would not stay behind bars for so many years.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: You talk about these being the most brute and harsh sentences, that it's the fear of the regime.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: But what do they say about Lukashenko's grip on power itself?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: So when it comes to the level of repressions in Belarus, it's been unprecedented.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Since the past year, since August 2020 more than 40 000 people have been imprisoned in Belarus and that's a an incredible number for Belarus our population is nine and a half million uh journalists are being jailed on a massive scale now there are currently 31 journalists behind bars many people were tortured and many people had to flee the country in fear of repressions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: So we have this repressions on the streets.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: So we have arrests, we have torture, but we also have now basically wiping out or cleansing the field of civil society.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: Lukashenko, his regime destroys institutions. Almost 300 institutions, organizations of civil society have been dissolved in the past months. So no dissent, no discontent is currently possible in Belarus and Lukashenko is so scared of protest that he wants to destroy anything that is still alive when it comes to organizations or institutions in Belarus and obviously there is this media blackout in the country. No independent media is available for Belarusians. They cannot watch it, they cannot read it. So basically Lukashenko wants to have citizens who are totally loyal to him. But again, given what he has done last year and obviously this year as well, people will not start loving him again. And I think that's what Lukashenko also understands.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: That's why he's so scared. All right, well, we're going to have to leave it there. But Hanna Lupakova, thank you so much for your analysis. Thank you so much.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: The World Health Organization says 77 countries have now reported cases of the COVID-19 variant

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Omicron and that it's probably in most countries, even if it hasn't been detected yet. Speaking at a press conference in Geneva, the WHO's director general said the new variant was spreading at a rate not seen by the international health body with previous ones. It was first reported last month in Southern Africa and Hong Kong.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: We're concerned that people are dismissing Omicron as mild.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_00
sentences.sentence: Surely, we have learned by now that we underestimate this virus at our peril.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Even if Omicron does cause less severe disease, the sheer number of cases could once again overwhelm unprepared health systems. In the UK, MPs are voting on the government's plan B COVID restrictions following the rapid spread of the Omicron variant. Health Secretary Sajid Javid addressed Parliament ahead of the vote, saying the vaccine rate across the country needs to be much higher. Javid announced that 11 countries on the UK's travel red list will be removed from 4am on Wednesday. He's now seeking urgent advice about people currently in quarantine hotels or ones who have been booked into hotels following the rule change now the Netherlands extended covid-19 restrictions on November 28 28th to try and deal with surging

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: infection numbers in the country but with the spread of the highly transmissible omicron variant the government is now considering putting further measures in place Let's bring in our reporter, Fernand Van Tetz, who joins us now from Amsterdam. Thank you so much for joining us now. So, Netherlands expected to extend current restrictions over Christmas. What's being considered?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So, we'll know exactly in an hour, Mayim, but what is being considered is, yes, extending that nighttime curfew that shops, restaurants, gyms close their doors at 5 p.m. until 5 a.m. the next morning. That will be extended at least until the 14th of January. It also means that the limitation on the number of visitors you can receive in your home, which is currently set to four, that will be extended over Christmas.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So that is a huge blow here.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And, actually, most controversially is the decision that elementary schools will have to shut their doors next week already, one week early for the Christmas holidays. That is in view of those Christmas celebrations coming up. They're hoping that, if children stop going to school, they will catch their infections early and hopefully not pass those on during Christmas celebrations. Now, secondary schools will be allowed to stay open. That's because a lot of children in secondary school have already been vaccinated. Elementary school children can only start being vaccinated as of January. And the number of cases has dipped for the first time here since yesterday. However, the number of people on intensive care units still continues to rise.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Nonessential care is still being delayed. And that pressure on the health system, that is why these measures will likely be announced to be extended until the 14th of January shortly. Right, so Fernand, nine months on from the election, looks like Mark Ritter will become Prime Minister again with a four-party coalition.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: What do we know about the agreement?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Yes, so he's made it in the end.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So, tomorrow, we will know the exact details.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So far, only positive things have been leaked by these four parties, the VVD of Prime Minister Mark Rutte, the Christian Democrats, the Liberal Democrats of D66, and the Christian Union.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: And that's things like lots of money to fight climate change, lots of money to fight a nitrogen excess scandal here, lots of money to invest a nitrogen excess scandal here, lots of money to invest in education, the potential of free childcare for everyone.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: However what has not been released yet, and that's the devil is in the details, is the issues that made it so difficult to form this coalition, the reason why this dragged on for 271 days, and that's issues like migration but also medical ethical issues like euthanasia where two of the parties really disagree on.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: So that we'll find out tomorrow how they manage to solve their differences and finally close the longest coalition formation in Dutch history.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_06
sentences.sentence: Definitely is the longest.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Fernanda, thank you so much for that update from the Netherlands.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Now, authorities in Greece have detained three people on suspicion of abducting a school teacher while they were carrying out COVID-19 checks.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Matthew in the Cube has more.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Mariam, across Europe we are still seeing examples of violence related to protests against health restrictions and COVID-19 vaccines.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: From deadly shootings in Germany and Russia to France where over the weekend a World War Two Memorial was vandalized by anti-pass demonstrators.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And in Greece this violence has targeted schools.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: On Friday a 61 year old head teacher at a school in the northern town of Katerina was abducted while they were carrying out daily Covid-19 checks as students entered the school premises.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Police said in a statement that this teacher was abducted, handcuffed and forced into a vehicle by a group of 11 self-styled vigilantes. They say this group then drove the teacher to a local police station where they tried to force the authorities to arrest this teacher for supposedly breaking constitutional freedoms. Instead, the police arrested this group of vigilantes. Three people have been detained pending a trial, eight others were released on bail.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: All of them facing charges related to abduction, assault and breaking health restrictions.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: And this kind of story has generated a huge reaction from the Greece government.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: A minister for public order said on Twitter that it was absolutely reprehensible.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: While Greece's minister for education, Niki Karameas, also said on Twitter that the instance was unthinkable and has pledged to protect the country's education community from further violence. Like many countries, Greece has seen an increasing instance of these kind of self-styled vigilantes. But like a number of countries, Mariam, Athens has pledged to crack down on this kind of COVID-19 related violence and of course as well on any criminals who are trying to profit from the pandemic.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: Thank you, Matthew.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Malta has become the first country in Europe to legalise the recreational use of cannabis.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: The Parliament voted in favour of the law, which also allows people to grow and store a limited amount of the drug at home.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Malta already allowed the use of medicinal cannabis back in 2018.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: For more, I'm now joined by Herman Gretsch, the editor of The Times of Malta.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: Good to have you on the programme. So, why is Malta taking the step?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: Well, it seems to have been... Malta's been making these incredible steps, I would say, more liberal steps in the last 11 years. This is an island where 11 years ago we didn't even have divorce legislation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: And we've gone from that to enacting divorce legislation. We introduced gay marriage and quite possibly the most progressive LGBT rights in Europe. So it came as almost the next progressive law by our government.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: This did not come easily. There's a lot of objections to the law. In fact, just a few minutes ago, the opposition leader said that basically they accused the government of bulldozing a law which he said would harm society and which ignored the advice of most NGOs.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: he said would harm society and which ignored the advice of most NGOs.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: So was there more opposition to making the use of cannabis legal then?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: There was quite a lot of opposition. I mean, there hasn't been any referendum or anything of the sort, but society, multi-society has changed. There is more tolerance towards these kinds of laws, which in the past would have been unthinkable.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: It's not because there's huge pressure from society to introduce it, but for the government, it seems to have been a more natural progression. The changes that have been going on in the last few years, it seems to have been next bit will be towards cannabis use. The government is saying, we're doing this because we need to stop, we need to clamp down on the criminals who are selling cannabis to, you know, we can't keep putting young people behind bars.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: But it went one step further, because now you can basically smoke cannabis at home.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: We need to be very careful. The law doesn not say that you can just go out and smoke it in the streets. This is for personal use and that you will be allowed to buy it from approved sellers. So what difference will this make really then to drug use on the island? And are then the public really behind this?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: We're not sure if really the public is behind it or not, because there are a lot of NGOs that have actually come out very strongly against this, because they're saying that it's saying that this will facilitate the use of harder drugs.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: The government made its case.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: They said it is not.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: They said that they're quite optimistic that this will simply clamp down on the criminals selling the drugs, and that it is better for our youths to be able to access drugs, soft drugs, through more approved means.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: We still don't know how this is going to go down, what changes, such as there's going to be on the ground, because in my books, it is not it is not really cannabis use in Malta.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: There is obviously clear use of cannabis, but it's not as widespread as possibly we think it is.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: OK, well, Herman Gretsch, editor of The Times of Malta, we're going to have to leave it there.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: But thank you so much for joining us.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: When you think of coffee countries like Brazil,, Colombia, Indonesia probably spring to mind.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: But now production is breaking ground in the Northern Hemisphere, and specifically Belgium, which claims the cultivation of its beans is more environmentally friendly and uses less energy.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: But there is much smaller supply, as Rebecca Daunt reports.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: This is grown, harvested and roasted in the heart of Liege.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: While most of the world's coffee comes from Brazil, the Plant World Observatory accomplished this particular feat using three Arabica coffee trees.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: The first harvest generated a mere 1.3 kilograms of coffee, enough to make 100 cups.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: For a fee of 6 euros, coffee lovers can enjoy a fresh cup of espresso.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_01
sentences.sentence: A bit subtle, a bit acidic, so pretty nice. You can tell the sweetness in this coffee.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_03
sentences.sentence: While coffee remains the world's second most popular drink, its cultivation leads to deforestation.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: However, with this tiny crop, it's different, says biologist Sophie Petours.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_09
sentences.sentence: We grow the coffee trees almost without fertilizer.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: And when we use fertilizer, it's organic fertilizer, no chemicals at all.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: In addition, the roasting process is completely traditional, so it's probably one of the best coffees you could find in terms of cost on the planet.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Once harvested, the beans were dried in a small machine before they were transported to a former coffee roaster just a few kilometres away.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: For Belgian coffee enthusiasts, the next tasting is scheduled for the 9th of January.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Rebecca Daunt, Euronews.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_05
sentences.sentence: And that's all from the programme, but we'll leave you with a no comment from Seville in Spain where supporters of Real Betis continued their annual tradition of throwing teddy bears onto the football pitch for disadvantaged children this Christmas.
